AE.Display.Animation2d.item#

class AE.Display.Animation2d.item(animation, name, **kwargs)#

Bases: object

Item of the animation (generic class)

Items are the elements displayed in the Animation2d.Qscene. This class provides a common constructor, conversions of positions to scene coordinates and styling of QAbstractGraphicsShapeItem children.

Attr:

animation (Animation2d): Parent animation.

name (str): Unique identifier of the item.

parent (item subclass): Parent item, if any.

position ([float, float]): Position of the item. See each subclass for

details.

zvalue (float): Z-value (stack order).

__init__(animation, name, **kwargs)#

Generic item constructor

Parameters:

  • animation (Animaton2d) – The animation container.

  • name (str) – Name of the item. It should be unique, as it is used as an identifier in the Animation2d.item dict.

  • parent (QGraphicsItem) – The parent QGraphicsItem.

  • zvalue (float) – Z-value (stack order).

  • position ([float, float]) – Position of the item. See each item’s documentation for a description.

  • draggable (bool) – If True, the element will be draggable. (default: False)

  • clickable (bool) – TO DO

a2scene(a)#

Convert an angle in scene coordinates (radian to degrees)

arg:

a (float): Angle to convert.

Returns:

The angle in degrees.

d2scene(d)#

Convert a distance in scene coordinates

arg:

d (float): Distance to convert.

Returns:

The distance in scene coordinates.

itemChange(change, value)#

Item change notification

This method is triggered upon item change. The item’s transformation matrix has changed either because setTransform is called, or one of the transformation properties is changed. This notification is sent if the ItemSendsGeometryChanges flag is enabled (e.g. when an item is item.movable), and after the item’s local transformation matrix has changed.

Parameters:

change (QGraphicsItem constant) –

mouseDoubleClickEvent(event)#

Double click event

For internal use only.

Parameters:

event (QGraphicsSceneMouseEvent) – The double click event.

mousePressEvent(event)#

Simple click event

For internal use only.

Parameters:

event (QGraphicsSceneMouseEvent) – The click event.

move(dx=None, dy=None, z=None)#

Relative displacement

Displaces the item of relative amounts.

dx#

\(x\)-coordinate of the displacement. It can also be a doublet [dx,`dy`], in this case the dy argument is overridden.

Type:

float

dy#

\(y\)-coordinate of the displacement.

Type:

float

z#

A complex number \(z = dx+jdy\). Specifying z overrides the x and y arguments.

Type:

float

place()#

Absolute positionning

Places the item at an absolute position.

x#

\(x\)-coordinate of the new position. It can also be a doublet [x,``y``], in this case the y argument is overridden.

Type:

float

y#

\(y\)-coordinate of the new position.

Type:

float

z#

A complex number \(z = x+jy\). Specifying z overrides the x and y arguments.

Type:

float

rotate(angle)#

Relative rotation

Rotates the item relatively to its current orientation.

angle#

Orientational increment (rad)

Type:

float

scene2x(u)#

Convert horizontal scene coordinates into \(x\) position

arg:

u (float): The horizontal coordinate.

Returns:

The \(x\) position.

scene2xy(pos)#

Convert scene coordinates into \(x\) and \(y\) positions

arg:

pos ([float,float]): The position in scene coordinates.

Returns:

The \(x\) and \(y\) positions.

scene2y(v)#

Convert vertical scene coordinates into \(y\) position

arg:

v (float): The horizontal coordinate.

Returns:

The \(y\) position.

setStyle()#

Item styling

This function does not take any argument, instead it applies the changes defined by each item’s styling attributes (e.g. color, stroke thickness).

x2scene(x)#

Convert the \(x\) position in scene coordinates

arg:

x (float): The \(x\) position.

Returns:

The \(x\) position in scene coordinates.

xy2scene(xy)#

Convert the \(x\) and \(y\) positions in scene coordinates

arg:

xy ([float,float]): The \(x\) and \(y\) positions.

Returns:

The \(x\) and \(y\) position in scene coordinates.

y2scene(y)#

Convert the \(y\) position in scene coordinates

arg:

y (float): The \(y\) position.

Returns:

The \(y\) position in scene coordinates.
